itemGroup.name: Shield (*)
entries: {@note This item group has the same name and source as the item {@item Shield|CompEquipMan}.}

itemGroup.name: Crossbow
entries: {@i A crossbow uses a horizontal bow attached to a wooden stock. The weapon's mechanism allows a bolt to be loaded and the weapon drawn, held in the firing position for much longer than a bow could be held manually. Crossbows are easier to aim and fire than traditional bows.}

itemGroup.name: Fustibalus
entries: {@i A long leather sling is attached to the end of this staff. The staff affectively adds length to the user's arm, allowing the sling to be used at greater range.}
This weapon has two profiles, one when used as a staff and the other for the sling. Weapon properties with each profile apply only to that type of use.

itemGroup.name: Lance
entries: {@i A long-hafted weapon with a sharp point, ideal for wielding from the back of a charging mount. A lance is long enough to brace it under the arm of the wielding hand, allowing it to be used one-handed if a mount provides the strikes' forward momentum.}

itemGroup.name: Combat Lance (*)
entries: {@note This item group has the same name and source as the item {@item Combat Lance|CompEquipMan}.}
You have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a combat lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.

itemGroup.name: Jousting Lance (*)
entries: {@note This item group has the same name and source as the item {@item Jousting Lance|CompEquipMan}.}
You have disadvantage when you use a jousting lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.
A jousting lance has a blunt end and is made to break away on impact. A creature wearing heavy armor has resistance to damage inflicted by a jousting lance.

itemGroup.name: Polearm
entries: {@i Polearms are long-hafted weapons, usually with complex, multi-purpose heads designed for war.}

itemGroup.name: Sword
entries: {@i Along with spears, swords are the most ubiquitous weapons on the battlefield, a weapon type used in nearly every culture. A sword consists of a handle affixed to the end of a long blade. A crosspiece usually separates the blade from the handle, protecting the wielder's hand.}

itemGroup.name: Rope
entries: {@i A rope is a twisted braid of strands. These are typically from a fibrous plant like hemp, or some non-plant alternative source, like silk.}
Rope, whether made of hemp or silk, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a {@dc 17} Strength check.

The effectiveness of placing a knot in a rope is determined with a Dexterity check, the result of which becomes the DC to untie the knot using another Dexterity check. (Alternately, a knot can be tied simply, requiring no check to untie it.) Tying or untying each knot requires an action.

A rope can be knotted at one-foot intervals for easier climbing. This reduces the rope's length by one-fifth and affords climbers advantage on Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks to climb it. Knotting or unknotting a 50-foot length of rope requires 1 minute.

itemGroup.name: Rope Ladder
entries: {@i A rope ladder consists of two parallel ropes connected by a series of short rungs, giving it the overall appearance and functionality of a ladder. At least half of the rungs are rigid wood or metal, holding the two ropes apart at a set distance.}

A rope ladder can be ascended or descended at the same speed as someone climbing a {@item rope|CompEquipMan}, except that no Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks are required. A rope ladder has 4 hit points and can be burst with a {@dc 19} Strength check.

itemGroup.name: Sheath
entries: {@i A sheath is a leather, wood, or metal covering for the blade of a weapon. It is designed to allow the weapon to be stored and carried with ease and safety.}

All weapons suitable for sheathes come with normal versions, included in their costs. Special sheaths normally add nothing to the combined weight of the weapon; they simply cost more based on their additional functionality. Not all weapons are suitable for sheathes; the Dungeon Master will determine which weapons are appropriate to have them.

itemGroup.name: Arcane Focus
entries: {@i Although arcane focuses come in many varieties, rods, staves, and wands—particularly when crafted from once-living material like bone or wood—make excellent focusing tools for magical power. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use these items as spellcasting focuses, as described in chapter 10 of the} {@book Player's Handbook|PHB|10|Material (M)}.

A magical rod, staff, or wand can be used as an arcane focus unless it requires attunement and cannot be attuned by the character trying to use it as such, or unless the text for the item says otherwise.

itemGroup.name: Druidic Focus
entries: {@i A druid can use these items as spellcasting focuses, as described in chapter 10 of the} {@book Player's Handbook|PHB|10|Material (M)}.

A magical staff or wand can be used as a druidic focus if it is made of wood, unless it requires attunement and cannot be attuned by the character trying to use it as such, or unless the text for the item says otherwise.

itemGroup.name: Holy Symbol
entries: {@i A cleric or paladin can use these items as spellcasting focuses, as described in chapter 10 of the} {@book Player's Handbook|PHB|10|Material (M)}.

itemGroup.name: Psionic Focus
entries: {@i Although psionic focuses come in many varieties, they are all made of crystal or have one or more prominent crystals attached to them. A psion, psychic warrior, or wilder can use these items as spellcasting focuses, as described in chapter 10 of the} {@book Player's Handbook|PHB|10|Material (M)}.
A magic item in the form of a circlet, dorje, or pendant can be used as a psionic focus, except when it requires attunement and cannot be attuned by the character trying to use it as such.
For more information on psionic focuses, see Wraith Wright's {@i Comprehensive Psionics Manual}.

itemGroup.name: Eggshell Grenade
entries: {@i Eggshell grenades are delicate alchemical devices that react dramatically when introduced to fire or an enemy's face. They are a favorite tool of rogues, often used to create distractions.}
As an action, you can throw an eggshell grenade up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. This requires a ranged attack, treating the grenade as an improvised weapon.

itemGroup.name: Artisan's Tools
entries: Proficiency with a set of {@item artisan's tools|CompEquipMan} lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make using the tools of your craft. Each type requires a different proficiency.

entries.name: Professional Work
entries: During downtime periods, {@item artisan's tools|CompEquipMan} let you craft items for yourself and others or earn a living.

entries.name: Repairs
entries: {@item Artisan's tools|CompEquipMan} are assumed to contain a small quantity of important components for repairing and upkeeping equipment without additional cost. For example, your {@item smith's tools|CompEquipMan} might contain extra links to replace lost bits of your {@item chain mail|CompEquipMan} armor.

Normally, this means that repairing an item requires only time, not additional costly materials. (Repair components are periodically restocked as incidental, untracked expenses.) The damaged parts of the gear itself counts as the materials needed for the project of crafting the item back to its completed form.

In the case of particularly-ruinous breakage, as suffered by armaments with the ersatz property, additional materials might need to be purchased, usually costing 5% of the item's normal price. This additional cost is also appropriate in the case of items ruined by such creatures as {@creature rust monster||rust monsters} and {@creature black pudding||black puddings}; anything that permanently degrades the item rather than giving it a broken status.

itemGroup.name: Musical Instrument
entries: If you have proficiency with a given musical instrument, you can add your proficiency bonus to ability checks to play the instrument. Proficiency also allows you to compose original music pieces, with or without lyrics. Each type of musical instrument requires a separate proficiency.

A bard can use a musical instrument as a spellcasting focus. Spellcasting this way, even without verbal components, creates sound; a musical instrument cannot be used as a spellcasting focus within a zone of {@spell silence}.
Use a musical instrument proficiency to identify a tune ({@dc 10}) or improvise a tune ({@dc 20}).

itemGroup.name: Barding
entries: {@i Barding is armor designed for mounts or other animals. It typically covers the head, neck, and body, leaving the legs free of impediment (and protection).}

Any armor shown on the {@table Armor|CompEquipMan} table in chapter 2 can be purchased or crafted as barding. The cost and weight are shown as multiples of the equivalent armor when made for humanoids. For example, a "x2" cost doubles what the armor would normally cost.

Canine barding typically fits all canines of the same size, and equine barding typically fits all equines of the same size. But exotic barding is made for animals of a specific type as well as a specific size.
For example, despite being the same size, a Large dragon's exotic barding cannot be transferred to a giant seahorse.

itemGroup.name: Bit and Bridle
entries: {@i Most mounts require some sort of head harness, something attached to a lead that is held by the rider. In the case of traditionally-trained mounts, a bit and bridle allow the rider to direct the animal and keep it under control.}

For optimal control, animals of various kinds require different sizes, shapes, and secondary functions built into these devices. For short-necked creatures, like dogs, this typically includes a collar.

Canine bridles typically fit canines of any size, and equine bridles typically fit equines of any size. But exotic bridles are made for animals of a specific type as well as a specific size. For example, despite being the same size, a Large dragon's exotic bridle cannot be transferred to a giant seahorse.

itemGroup.name: Body Harness
entries: {@i These sets of secure straps serve multiple functions. Typically, they allow an animal to draw vehicles such as carts or wagons, attaching the worn harness to one or two of the vehicle's forwardpointing shafts. The straps are placed in such a way as to distribute the force evenly across the most accommodating surface of the animal's body. A body harness can also be re-configured to help lift or carry an animal. In this case, straps are shifted to more supportive positions on the animal's body, suitable to raise or lower it, perhaps via block and tackle. Travelers navigating rough terrain may find such tools necessary to bring their mounts across steep hills, cliffs, or similar obstacles.}

itemGroup.name: Cage
entries: {@i A cage is large enough for an animal of the listed size to stand within it, turn around fully, and lie down. (A winged creature does not have space to fully spread its wings.) A cage's size rating must fit a contained creature's size exactly; too small a cage prevents the creature from fitting into it while too large a cage might allow the creature to escape through the spacing in the bars.}

Cages are made of iron, with Armor Class 19. These resilient objects usually have hit points/damage threshold as follows: Tiny (5/1), Small (10/2), Medium (18/4), Large (27/6), Huge (39/8), and Gargantuan (54/12). Because they are constructed to resist intentional breakage by their contained creatures, cages are typically immune to damage from natural attacks. Additional information on the health of objects can be found at {@book page 246|DMG|8|Objects} of the Dungeon Master's Guide.

itemGroup.name: Feed
entries: {@i The type of food needed for different animals varies significantly. Omnivores can typically eat any kind of feed, as well as rations. Herbivores, particularly equines, can survive on grass, hay, and other herbaceous plants. High-value feed, like oats, is simply a luxury and is unhealthy for such animals to eat all the time. Dogs and other carnivores require meat for most of their diet. As feed, this typically takes the form of dried meat scraps or meat ground up with absorbent grains. Meat feed lasts for only a week before it becomes spoiled and worthless.}

Most creatures can forage or hunt for themselves, given enough time and left to their own devices. Feed is only needed when animals are kept caged or stabled, worked or ridden longer than eight hours in a day, or otherwise prevented from finding their own food for significant portions of the day. Tiny creatures need only 1/4 pound of food per day for sustenance. Small and Medium creatures need 1 pound. Large creatures need 4 pounds, Huge creatures need 16 pounds, and Gargantuan creatures need 64 pounds of food per day. The DM is the final arbiter of each animal's needs for quantity and type of food.

itemGroup.name: Howdah
entries: {@i A howdah is a partially-enclosed platform mounted on an animal. It surrounds one or more riders, offering protection from attackers or from the elements. Most howdahs include a roof.}

One Medium- or Small-sized rider can fit in the howdah of a Large creature. Most Large creatures are not quite big enough for a howdah, but camels are a notable exception. Four Medium- or Small-sized riders can fit in the howdah of a Huge creature. Sixteen Medium- or Small-sized riders can fit in the howdah of a Gargantuan creature. Riders in howdahs have half cover from the attacks of creatures on the ground if those creatures are smaller than the mount.

itemGroup.name: Muzzle
entries: {@i Muzzles are each made for animals of a specific type and size. A muzzle prevents the wearer from biting or eating. It also makes dangerous-looking animals appear to be safer, meaning bystanders are often less intimidated and more accepting of their presence.}

A muzzle takes one action to apply or remove. At the DM's discretion, this can prevent the handler from having to make Wisdom ({@skill animal handling||Handle Animal}) checks under some circumstances.

itemGroup.name: Canine Saddle
entries: {@i Saddles for dogs are lightweight and built to accommodate the greater range of motion that dogs have over equine mounts.}

Such saddles are also suitable for wolves of Large or Medium size and similar creatures. A {@item Military Canine Saddle|CompEquipMan|military} version gives the rider advantage on any check to remain mounted. A {@item Pack Canine Saddle|CompEquipMan|pack} version has no accommodation for a rider; it simply provides a frame to which baggage can be tied.

itemGroup.name: Equine Saddle
entries: {@i An equine saddle fits horses and ponies as well as donkeys and mules. It also fits similar equine creatures such as unicorns.}

Equine saddles are not suited for equines with additional limbs or wings like a pegasus. (Such a creature requires an {@item exotic saddle|CompEquipMan} instead.) A {@item Military Equine Saddle|CompEquipMan|military} version gives the rider advantage on any check or saving throw to remain mounted. A {@item Pack Equine Saddle|CompEquipMan|pack} version has no accommodation for a rider; it simply provides a frame to which baggage can be tied.

itemGroup.name: Exotic Saddle
entries: {@i Creatures not in the shape of equines (horses, mules, etc.) or canines (dogs, wolves, etc.), require exotic saddles to use as mounts or beasts of burden.}

Exotic saddles are each made for animals of a specific type and size. For example, despite being the same size, a Large dragon's riding saddle cannot be used on a giant seahorse. A {@item Military Exotic Saddle|CompEquipMan|military} version of an exotic saddle gives the rider advantage on any check or saving throw to remain mounted when the animal is not climbing, flying, or moving underwater. A {@item Pack Exotic Saddle|CompEquipMan|pack} version of an exotic saddle has no accommodation for a rider; it simply provides a frame to which baggage can be tied.

Creatures capable of burrowing cannot do so without automatically dismounting their riders, regardless of saddle type. Creatures capable of other three-dimensional movement (climbing, flying, or underwater travel) require strap saddles to keep riders secure. {@item Strap Saddle|CompEquipMan|Strap saddles} require the rider to use two actions to strap in after mounting, performed by the rider or by aides. Thereafter, the rider cannot be dismounted short of very exceptional circumstances (like the mount burrowing). Using a strap saddle without strapping in is treated as using a riding saddle. The Dungeon Master may impose riding checks every round to stay mounted in cases of climbing, flying, pouncing, and (particularly) underwater travel while not strapped in or while using another type of saddle.

itemGroup.name: Military Exotic Saddle
entries: {@i Creatures not in the shape of equines (horses, mules, etc.) or canines (dogs, wolves, etc.), require exotic saddles to use as mounts or beasts of burden.}
A military exotic saddle gives the rider advantage on any check or saving throw to remain mounted when the animal is not climbing, flying, or moving underwater.

itemGroup.name: Pack Exotic Saddle
entries: {@i Creatures not in the shape of equines (horses, mules, etc.) or canines (dogs, wolves, etc.), require exotic saddles to use as mounts or beasts of burden.}
A pack exotic saddle has no accommodation for a rider; it simply provides a frame to which baggage can be tied.

itemGroup.name: Riding Exotic Saddle
entries: {@i Creatures not in the shape of equines (horses, mules, etc.) or canines (dogs, wolves, etc.), require exotic saddles to use as mounts or beasts of burden.}
Exotic saddles are each made for animals of a specific type and size. For example, despite being the same size, a Large dragon's riding saddle cannot be used on a giant seahorse.

itemGroup.name: Strap Saddle
entries: {@i Creatures not in the shape of equines (horses, mules, etc.) or canines (dogs, wolves, etc.), require exotic saddles to use as mounts or beasts of burden.}

Creatures capable of burrowing cannot do so without automatically dismounting their riders, regardless of saddle type. Creatures capable of other three-dimensional movement (climbing, flying, or underwater travel) require strap saddles to keep riders secure. {@item Strap Saddle|CompEquipMan|Strap saddles} require the rider to use two actions to strap in after mounting, performed by the rider or by aides. Thereafter, the rider cannot be dismounted short of very exceptional circumstances (like the mount burrowing). Using a strap saddle without strapping in is treated as using a riding saddle. The Dungeon Master may impose riding checks every round to stay mounted in cases of climbing, flying, pouncing, and (particularly) underwater travel while not strapped in or while using another type of saddle.

itemGroup.name: Galley
entries: {@i These long, slender warships are propelled mainly by rowing, but they also have masts and can travel under sail.}

itemGroup.name: Longship
entries: {@i These vessels are long, low ships used for trade and commerce as well as warfare. Each is propelled by a single, large sail or by oars. When used as warships, the passengers and crew typically mount their shields along the gunnels of both sides to provide additional protection and to intimidate foes. The tall prows and aft ends of longships are often carved as the heads of dragons or other ferocious beasts.}

itemGroup.name: Combination Gun
entries: {@i This weapon sees many configurations. It consists of a firearm of pistol caliber attached to a melee weapon of some sort. Because of the awkwardly-formed nature of these guns and their propensity for getting jarred repeatedly in melee combat, they are slightly less reliable than normal firearms.}
This weapon loads ball or shot.

entries.name: Special
entries: A combination gun blends a single-barrel firearm with a melee weapon. Using the weapon as a firearm employs the combination gun stat line on the table, except as described below. Using it as a melee weapon employs the derived melee weapon's normal statistics, as modified according to the rules here.

To create a combination gun, select a melee weapon that normally weighs 1 pound or more. Add 60 gp to the melee weapon's cost and add 2 pounds to its weight. The melee weapon portion of a combination gun loses its thrown property, if any. If the melee weapon portion has the versatile or two-handed property, the firearm portion loses its handgun property.

itemGroup.name: Mixed-Use Gun
entries: {@i This breach-loading weapon has two scattergun barrels and a regular cartridge barrel. Its versatility makes it popular for hunting.}

The two scattergun barrels load shotshells or slugs and use the shorter set of the listed range increments. The third barrel loads a (rifle) cartridge and uses the longer set of the listed range increments.

itemGroup.name: Ship of the Line
entries: {@i These "men o' war" are large, multi-deck ships capable of carrying hundreds of people. They are built to project national power upon the high seas. All ships of the line are built to sling a staggering weight of stone or iron from siege engines, slugging it out with other ships of the line during fleet actions.}

itemGroup.name: Unrated Ship
entries: {@i Unrated ships are capable vessels but do not have the military designations that describe the roles of naval craft.}

itemGroup.name: Warship
entries: {@i These frigates are built for war with multiple decks. They are still small enough to be moved by oars, but large enough to find a place in major engagements. In fleet actions, frigates serve the role of support ships.}

spell.name: Basic Rite

components.m: Powdered gold of a value described below

entries: You perform one of several arcane rites. When you cast the spell, choose one of the following rites. Its target must be within 10 feet of you throughout the casting. This spell is particularly useful in societies where arcane tools are illegal or hard to acquire.

entries.name: Etch Weapon
entries: You touch an appropriate weapon, empowering it as an {@item Weapon Etching|CompEquipMan|etching} arcane focus. (50 gp)

entries.name: Empower Rod
entries: You convert an {@item aklys|CompEquipMan}, {@item club|CompEquipMan}, {@item hanbo|CompEquipMan}, {@item hotchiku|CompEquipMan}, or {@item knobkerrie|CompEquipMan} to a {@item rod|CompEquipMan} arcane focus. (10 gp)

entries.name: Empower Staff
entries: You can turn a {@item bo|CompEquipMan}, {@item crook|CompEquipMan}, {@item fustibalus|CompEquipMan}, or {@item quarterstaff|CompEquipMan} into a {@item staff|CompEquipMan} arcane focus. A {@item shikomizue|CompEquipMan} can likewise be empowered but only works as a focus when the sword is sheathed. (5 gp)

entries.name: Suffuse Ink
entries: You can enchant a one-ounce vial of ink, dark ink, or glowing ink, making it "{@item rare ink (1-ounce bottle)|CompEquipMan|rare}," sufficient for wizards transcribing spells into their spellbooks without additional cost. (100 gp)

spell.name: Sacrament

components.m: Rare herbs of a value described below

entries: You perform one of several nature-inspired sacraments.
When you cast the spell, choose one of the following effects. Its target must be within 10 feet of you throughout the casting.

entries.name: Awaken Sickle
entries: You touch a {@item sickle|CompEquipMan}, empowering it to serve as a {@item ritual sickle|CompEquipMan} druidic focus. (2 gp)

entries.name: Embellish Weapon
entries: You can turn a touched weapon of the appropriate sort into a {@item weapon embellishment|CompEquipMan} druidic focus. (25 gp)

entries.name: Empower Staff
entries: You can turn a {@item bo|CompEquipMan}, {@item crook|CompEquipMan}, {@item fustibalus|CompEquipMan}, or {@item quarterstaff|CompEquipMan} into a {@item wooden staff|CompEquipMan} druidic focus if it is made of wood. (5 gp)

spell.name: High Ceremony

m.text: 100 gp worth of powdered electrum or platinum

entries: You perform one of several religious ceremonies.
When you cast the spell, choose one of the following ceremonies. Its target must be within 10 feet of you throughout the casting.

entries.name: Bless Water
entries: You touch up to four vials of water and cause them to become {@item holy water (flask)|CompEquipMan|holy water}.

entries.name: Consecrate Ground
entries: You dedicate a temple, shrine, or other place significant to your religion, affecting an area no more than 100 feet across. For the next 24 hours, creatures within the area can't be {@condition frightened}. During this period, the area detects as consecrated to a detect evil and good spell or a paladin's Divine Sense feature.

entries.name: Coronation
entries: In the name of a deity or pantheon, you crown the ruler of a kingdom or similar realm. This requires the additional material component of a crown of some sort. Once per year, while the ruler maintains divine favor (a story element dictated by the Dungeon Master), the ruler may cure a diseased creature with a touch. At the Dungeon Master's discretion, additional capabilities may be imparted.

entries.name: Curse Water
entries: You touch up to four vials of water and cause them to become {@item unholy water (flask)|CompEquipMan|unholy water}.

entries.name: Ordain Weapon
entries: You touch an appropriate weapon, empowering it to serve as a {@item Ordained Weapon|CompEquipMan|divine focus}.

condition.name: Lesser Poisoned
entries: The lesser poisoned condition is noted by parenthetically listing one or more abilities after the condition. For example, a creature affected with the "poisoned (Strength)" condition has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks, but only the ones that utilize Strength. Likewise, a creature affected by the "poisoned (Intelligence, Charisma)" condition has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks based on Intelligence and Charisma.
Lesser poisoned conditions are in all other ways equivalent to the standard {@condition poisoned} condition and can be resisted or removed in the same way.

trait.name: Unreliable
entries: Apply disadvantage to any Wisdom (Handle Animal) checks made to control this mount in battle or to get it to perform tricks or difficult maneuvers.

trait.name: Unstable
entries: This animal gains 1 {@condition exhaustion} level for each hour of a forced march; this is additional to any {@condition exhaustion} from failing the Constitution check.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

feat.name: Firearms Expert
entries: Having practiced extensively with firearms of various sorts, you gain the following benefits:

items: You are proficient with all firearms and with tinker's tools.
Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged attack rolls with any firearm.
Double the number of ammunition pieces you can normally load into a single firearm with each action or bonus action, up to the weapon's capacity.
